Probably my favourite of the bunch. Dark brown/black with plenty of the requisite chocolate and barley notes on the nose. Very dry in the mouth but with enough herbal hop notes to keep it interesting and a hoppy rather than astringent bitter finish.
A very nice roasted flavor, but lacking aftertaste. A watery mouthfeel. Almost black in color with a light brown head.
Bottle. Pours an extremely dark brown with almost no head on it. Nose is very dry and fairly bitter. Taste has a similar dry bitterness to it and just doesnt seem well balanced.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2013 I was dying to try their Oyster Stout, but this was the only one I could get hold of. A bit disappointed with the excesses. Too bitter, too dry. Fabulous appearance, oily - and oily aroma, by the way, but too leathery. The flavours of roasted malts are overwhelmed by the bitterness. Not too nice. The palate is just bitter, sticky, and not very pleasing. Im sure these guys have done a much better job on their oyster stout...at least I hope so.

33 cl bottle from Doorstep Brew. Sampled on December 22, 2012. Marked 5.7% ABV, BB 02 11 12.Clear very dark brown color, brown head. Sweet, chocolate, cola, juniper, spicy scent. Grainy, dry, chocolate taste. Dry bitter finish. Medium mouthfeel, medium to medium high bitterness.A bit too dry and bitter for me to fully enjoy it.

tan/black colour, little lace and almost no head. High roast aroma although muted,light grain and some dark fruit. Roasted/burnt toast bitterness, with a dry finish but little in terms of body and complexity. I like the bitterness and roast about this brew and gets high marks for style but shows little complexity in its youth.

Tap at Porterhouse, Covent Garden - 13/12/12.
Mid black with a sizeable tan head that retains well.
Nose is dark malt, mineral and metallic tones, hint of chocolate.
Taste is bitter roast malt, bitter dark chocolate, touch of mineral and iron.
Medium bodied, soft carbonation, smooth on the palate, roasted dry finish.
Ok drinkable stout - no world beater.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
(5.7% version)
Black with a frothy, light brown head.
Scent is ashy, dark chocolate, coffee.........
Taste is smoky, dark fruit, coffee bitter and malt.
Very dry.
A nicely done stout.
Aroma is one of beers most complex features. Aroma is propelled by lively CO2 and dampened by pillowy heads - especially nitrogen foam. Click on a term below to add it to your tasting notes.

330 ml bottle. Pours black with medium tan head that dissipates quickly. Aromas of burnt malts, dark chocolate, ash, and chalk. Very dry. Flavors of pure dark chocolate, black coffee, and light malts. Bitter finish.

Bottle.  Pours pitch black with a smooth large, white head. Aroma has notes of roasted malts, coffee, ash and smoke. Taste is quite roasty with notes of smoke, fruits and coffee. Finish is dry and bitter. Well balanced, nice dry stout.

11.2oz bottle in an English pint.  Pours very dark brown with a lacy, beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts, some dough, light chocolate, pale malts, and floral hops.  Flavor about what a dry stout should be, but could have more malts, like always.  Average texture.  A pretty good beer.

330ml bottle. Pours coffee black, not much of a head. What there was disappeared quickly. Dusty roast malt, grain and vanilla character in the aroma. Lovely balance of dry and sweet characteristics in the flavour, sweet, slightly burnt malts offset by dry, slightly acriad English hop character. Oily palate. Finish lingers forever, bitterness comes to the fore here with a twist of licquorice. Great stuff.

Sample at Porterhouse Central. Brownish-black pour with a medium tan head that dissipates slowly. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Aroma of toasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Light-bodied with a burnt malt character along with flavors of dark chocolate and espresso. The finish is roasty with a lingering black coffee aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

Full cartessing body is beautifully balanced with the tingle of tasty sourness a very long and very satisfyling  complimenting an almost earthy dryness. You can its every element yet they all combine to make a gorgeous whole.Grand.
Chocolate malt with alcoholic notes. Black in colour with a frothy head. Smooth texture. Chocolate coffee flavour with a pleasant roasted finish.
Bottle (0,33l) from Getränkeland, Hvidovre. Roasted aroma with hints of coffee. Pours pitch black with a light tan head. Tastes like coffee too, dry and roasted. Best Stout Ive tasted yet.
16th December 2010Dark brown beer, semi transparent. Little off white head. Light dry palate. Mild roasty malt with a little tang. Trace of fruit. Dry finish. Ho hum!
Pours a very dark brown with a one finger light brown head. Some coffee in the background, but upfront dry roasty notes dominate, with a bitter finish. A good stout to have with a meal like a burger.

Jet black nitro pour with a creamy off white head. Aroma: roasted malt, hops, grain, touch of coffee, chocolate, peat and fruit. Tasty, full bodied stout with the different flavours nicely balanced, although Wrasslers finishes slighlty bitter.

Bottle, purchased just days ago at Dutchs curbside bottle shop. Its pour is dark-almost-black brown with a thick, sandy espresso foam head. When it comes to length of head, I dont think I would like to count the fingers for this one. Smells ans tastes predominately of seawater, charcoal, hops, lilac, and bittersweet chocolate. Yeast and cornstarch at swallow. Drinkable.

courtesy of Per - black beer with a firm and persistent beige foam; gently roasted nutty and coffeish aroma; slightly lactic, creamy palate and medium-bodied; tasty and decently bitter; roasted aftertaste of tar, ashes and walnuts

Rich black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, grain/hops, & some coffee; Flavor of roasted/burnt malt, caramel, coffee, hops, and some chocolate; Finish is fairly bitter; Overall, I enjoyed this one.

This is also a great full stout.  Pours an open cream coloured head.  The flavour is deep, malt and some treacle burnt caramel.  Medium body.  Very dry finish which leaves interesting flavours in the mouth.

At The Wharf, Aalborg, DK.
Tap, 041012.
Black with white head. Aroma of roasted malt. Flavour with coffee and some fruit.

10/3/12. 12oz bottle. Deep black pour with a nice tan head. Rich aroma of chocolate, coffee, roast, hints of butterscotch, a touch of sourness, and some oxidation. Rich flavor of chocolate and coffee with a dry roasty bitterness and a touch of tartness. The bottle may be a touch old, but this is still tasty.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2012 Fra flaske på Cardinal: en tørr og smaksrik stout, rund og behagelig. Fin røstet aroma med (naturlig nok) kaffe og sjokolade. God ettersmak. Denne prøver jeg gjerne igjen. Enda bedre fra cask på Charlies Bar i København: myk&samtidig stor i smaken.
Bottle pours close to black. Nice big head. Smells and tastes roasted malt caramel hops. Not bad same as another I had kind of thin creamy. Sweet. Not that great.

Bottle.  Black beer with a strong frothy brown head.  The aroma is lightly roasted, and the flavour has a greater degree of roasted'ness with a creamy mouth feel and a deep bitterness.  Overall a good strongly flavoured bitter coffee flavoured roasted stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

For a beer that is only 5% this one of the most intense, flavorful stout, I have ever have. its true all to burnt toasty malty with a nice light hoppy presence is exactly what the stout style should be like. it has a richness that is full palate with a strong bitter bite that does not let go. this is a true stout in every sense of the word. drink up!!!

330ml bottle. Opaque brown with red highlights and a mountain of tan head that leaves lots of spider web lace down the glass. Surprising amount of hops on the nose, a very vegetal, earthy hoppiness. Under that theres lots of caramel and milk chocolate, a certain...mintiness? I have reminiscences of cough drops....or ice cream. Touch of vanilla. Coffee hits first on the palate. Lots of roasty bitterness. A letdown from everything the nose had going on. Finishes long and bitter. Good, but Im still disappointed in the palate.

330 ml bottle, Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 5.7%. Pitch black colour, large to moderate beige head. Nice roasty aroma, notes of mild coffee and dark chocolate, hints of woodwork. The flavour is quite dry and distinctly roasty, strong coffee notes with some woody hints. Long and bitter aftertaste.

Bottle.

Head is initially large, creamy, brown, fully lasting.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, bitter chocolate, husks), with notes of enamel paint, plaster/paper, and egg whites.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter, husky.

Medium body, creamy texture, lively/soft carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Dirty/phenolic/husky nose, a grainy finish, and fairly strong sourness make this quite unpleasant.  Which is sad because the lasting creamy head looks lovely, and the mouthfeel is equally creamy.

Bottle with pull-off cap, at home, 0.33l. An interresting stout. Definitely not a generic stout as so many are. First visuals; almost completely black, but hold it up to a strong light its deep red. Pours a thick and nice looking brown foam. Taste comes off as very malty and bitter and has a long roasty aftertaste. Surprisingly flavoury for a stout with this little alcohol, but ultimately not one Id want to drink again. Good and different - and Im glad I tried it - but not a favourite.
This is a very good brew.  Just tried the oyster stout, like that much better.
Ottima stout, con aroma forte di caffè e cioccolato molto armonici tra loro...finale lungo e deciso
scura buona schiuma persitente tostaure piuttosto intense buon corpo buon amaro finale abbastanza asciutto

Bottle with ring-pull. Not bottle conditioned, but a fair bit of pressure. Pours thick and gloopy. Almost black, with some red around the edges, where the light just gets through. Pours thick, nice & creamy, brown head (slightly metallic taste to it though), diminishing fairly quickly to consistent covering. Medium carbonation. Aroma - Lovely rich roasted, ashy dark chocolate, strong licorice, along with some slightly sweeter caramellish malt notes and some faint, spicy hops. Taste is rich, chocolatey sweet and good lightly ashy roast, with good hopping. Also some slight sweet fruitiness; dark fruits and brown sugar. Slight bitter, roasted flavours left on tongue, lingering. Body is fairly heavy, slightly creamy. A nice rich, roasty, chocolatey Irish stout; not as dry as you would expect from the roasty aroma. Very nice.

0.33l bottle. Nice and a bit different bottle. It has a fingerprint that suits a right-handed person, and a different pull-off cap. It pours quite a nice deep dark reddish - almost what you could call black actually - body, and it has a medium sized chocolate-ashy almost fluffy head thats floating on top of the beer. On the aroma this is light sweet roasted, I get chocolate and chocolate paper, dark and red fruits and perhaps even some tones of both coffee and caramel. Its not extreme, but its pretty darn nice! On the flavor I get lots of cold coffee! It continues with roasted malts, acidity and chocolate. Ends a bit watery without being confusing or annoying, and its leaving a lasting light dry tongue. Yeah, a different experience with the pull-off cap (my first time ever actually), and it tasted quite alright. 07.06.2012
Strong aroma and flavor. Large head  on top on a completely opaque and pitch black beer. Heavy body. Flavors of a strong roasted peat with a hint of grape. Very dry with a lingering aftertaste.

Draft at the wharf. Pitch black with a thick (whipped creme) tan head. Quite hoppy aroma, but burnt malts dominate. Full bodied, creamy mouthfell. A lot of dark roasted malts, more than your average 5% stout. Long aftertaste, hoppy and burnt.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330ml bottle. Clear darkest brown with average to huge, frothy to creamy, moderately lacing, tan head. Dark malty aroma with roasty notes, a touch of dark fruit. Taste is initially minimally sweet dark malty with hints of chocolate, gains a more dry and roasty touch, reaches a bitter hoppy finish.

11.2oz bottle. Thin brown head, black color. Some lace. Nice roasty (slightly burnt) malt aroma. Good hop balance. Thin and light compared to the American stouts that Im used to. Crisp carbonation, dry finish. Nice lighter-bitterness. Solid Irish-style stout.

Deep black pour.  Ruby on the edges with a nice tan head.  Aroma is bitter roast malt and some good scotch notes.  Deep malty roast.  Really nice aroma.  Flavor is roasted malt.  A little bitter but not over the top.  Some really deep flavor notes.  Really good dry dark bitter beer.
On tap at the porterhouse central in Dublin.Irish stout with a reàlly strong taste. Stronger than the oyster and the plain. I recommend once in a while for people who like strong stout.
Beer was not very good.  The finish was very much of rubbing alcohol.  I will say the description on there website was pretty accurate, which does not suite my taste at all.

Bottle from Beers Of Europe, Kings Lynn, 5.7% ABVBlack color, small but nice looking head, beige, some bubbles over creamy base. The roasted malt aroma is quite nice, maybe with a trace of apples. The mouthfeel is very dry, with strong roasted malt flavor, black coffee, light paper; the extreme roastiness burns the tongue in the final.Too much burnt stuff.

Tap at Oblivion. Upon the first whiff of this one and I thought I was drinking a smoked beer. Tons of peat malt, charcoal, light bbq notes, and some earthy dry chocolate. Flavors match the nose with a touch less roast (even though its still the dominate flavor here) and more chocolate notes. Pours like a typical stout. Creamy. I like this style but its super smokey for what Ive had of this style. Not bad, though, as I loved smoked brews.

This beer wasnt that bad - but how is the style not smoked? It tastes lightly of smoked bacon wrapped around dark chocolate. The aroma is smoky as well, and gives off a nice scent of smoked meat, wet dog and cocoa. Eh all that though and I still enjoyed it!

The aroma is bittter chocolate, burnt caramel, roast.  The appearance is deep brown, slight reddish hue, light translucence on the edges.  The flavor is dry as a motherf%^&*.  Non-sweet chocolate, bitter, roasty, coffee, burnt caramel.  The finish is dry, roasty, bitter chocolate.  Medium to medium/thick in body.  Thicker than a lot of dry stouts out there.  Cool example of this style.  At $4.29 for 12 oz, its also overpriced.

330ml bottle. Pours thick black with thin tan head. Smokey, charcoal aroma - like a distant BBQ. Delicious chocolate and coffee taste the fills the mouth. Leaves a lingering malt taste that is quite dry. Another winner from Porterhouse. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours black with brown head. Aroma of strong coffee.  Flavor of bitter coffee. Has a medium thick mouthfeel.

Pours almost opaque with reddish tint under bright light.  Perfect, deep tan head that stays forever.  Smells of ashtray, charcoal, and chocolate.  Bitter charcoal and coffee flavors.  Smooth, creamy mouthfeel.  Bitter, slightly sticky linger.
Black body, brown head. Roasted malty aroma with coffee, some mocha. Dry malty flavour with roasted coffee, dark chocolate. Very nice.
on tap-pours black with a tan head.  Aroma is roasty dark malt-molasses.  Taste is roasty dark malt-molasses/chocolate, earthy hops.  Drying.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Bottle. Very dark pour with a brown head. Aroma of whiskey, roasted malts, and wood. Moderate palate. Taste is light whiskey and sharp bitter coffee. Very good!

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2015 Nice and full, hoppy dry stout with creamy body, sensual bitter chocolate and almost no cloying sweetness, even a hint of spicy tartness. Ptich black with a nice and full creamy head. - Still celebrating Bloomsday 2012, had this with a gorgonzola toast. - Perfect match made in Irish beer heaven - eager to try more of the Porterhouses brews now. Anyone know a good German import for their other beers?  // Resampled 33cl as 4xStout at 5,6% instead of 5% - bb12/2016: quite robust and charred malt bitter, really. But enjoyably so. Red berry components in the hops.

Pours black with a thinner tan head.  Rich aroma with cherry, chocolate, raisin.  Earthy as well.  Taste is more fruity, with the raisin and cherry, and even some lemon.  Kind of sour, almost vinegar.  Very dry, with that unusual sour aftertaste.  Not bad in my opinion.  Quite different than your average stout.

Draft (4,3%) at The Porterhouse in Dublin. Black with a creamy light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt with dark and bitter chocolate and a hint of coffee and fruits. Malrty and lightly sweet with a nice bitterness in the finish. Creamy, medium body. Bitter and roasty aftertaste. The best Irish stout I have tasted. Very pleasant! (2011-06-11)

330ml bottle.  Poured a deep black color with a thick whipped cream like tan head that hung around. Mild aroma of nuts and cocoa.  Taste was big roasty and sweet malts with some hints of nuts and chocolate. Thick, creamy slick mouthfeel with mild carbonation.

Bottle sample at a tasting in our place. Thanks beerandbeyond. Coke-coloured, dark tan foam head. Sweet, almost berry-like aroma, also smoke and peat. Bitter, peat acetic taste. Smooth, very light carbonation, slightly smokey. Good.
Black, with a brown head. Smells like chocolate and rum, with some coffee and raisin. Taste is also chocolate, the some sweet fruity notes. Dry, slightly woody finish.

5.7% 330ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Quite an attractive beer: deep mahogany coloured body with a large, dense & creamy tan head with good retention. Juicy, lightly tangy red & dark fruits on the nose with notes of liquorice, chocolate, coffee & all slightly vinuous. More of those sweet/sour prune, rum raisin tones on the tongue supported by a slight earthiness & a rich dark roasted malt, choccy, coffee bitterness. Medium body, soft to medium carbonation with a lingering, dry finish.

On tap at the brew pub the star of the night.  Hefty nose, coffee plus dark chocolate.  Dark tan head.  Very creamy smooth palate , a touch oily, lighter than I expected.  Hoppy, gritty finish.  Fluffy retention.  Really nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

5.7% abv.Black pour with some short head with lacing and good froth.Some red hue.
Aroma is complex of  mellowhops and malt roast chocolate,sweet carmel,all subtle but genuinely nice.
Taste is full bodied malt bittersweet dark chocolate,refined smooth hops, very roasty  with dark toffee slight coffee but just  pretty dark roasty some good breadiness underneath all the roast. Some dry woody cherry bourbon qualities.Smooth and bitter with bittersweet chocolate.Very good.

Bottle. Low but lasting fluffy light brown head. Very dark red brown, almost black, body. Bitter sweet coffee roasted malt hops aroma. In spite of the relatively low alcohol percentage the brewers of this beer have managed to produce a powerful and heavily roasted malt flavor with coffee and a good deal of hops bitterness. The high carbonation and long aftertaste makes it a nice experience.
(Bottle 31/03-2012) Medium brown head, black color, roasted coffee aroma, low to medium co2, dry roasted bitter taste. BB date 02.11.2012.

Clear black body with red highlights, creamy tan head, nice lacing. Aroma is medium sweet, coffee, some chocolate, roasty. Taste is medium sweet, roasty coffee, with a coffee bitter finish. Creamy light-medium body

Black with a melanoidin and sasparilla underpinning, ok head. Appreciable dryish roastyness smells playful waft off the glass bifurcating into caramel and toffee notes. The body is characterized by a deep chocolate vein and roasty maltiness, with the definite influence of caramel. Full-bodied, nice complexity, and quite satisfying.
Nice dark pour with thick creamy head. Fair amount of roasted malts. Not much alchohol.

11.2 oz bottle pours black with a tan head.  Aroma and taste are standard stout.  Roasted malts, coffee and chocolate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This was the last tasted at the Porterhouse pub in Dublin on 3 March.  By far the most complex of the stouts I had in Ireland.  The stout poured a pitch black with a creamy tan head.  There was lacing with this medium body stout.  This stout had more bite and the hops were more dominent than their other stouts.  Flavors of chocolate and coffee from the begining to end and maybe some smoke and licorice as well.   The finish was smooth with a hint of bitterness. This is great stout and I can see why it was a favorite of Michael Collins.
Black with a cream head. Aroma of plum, with a medium sweetness. Flavour stats sweet but quickly comes to a creamy roast bitterness. Palate is fruit bittersweet.
Gotta love the pull-top cap. Pours dark brown, not too surprisingly, with a thin tan head. Aroma is bitter and grainy. Taste is coffee and roasted malt with a dry, bitter finish.

330 mL bottle.  Pours to a deep cola colored body with a thin head.  Aromas of catty hops like what I think of Point Cascade Pale Ale.  The flavor is simply dry roasty malts with a light catty like hops.  Simple palate thats a little dry.

Tasted from a cool sloped bottle with unusual peel-back cap into nonic pint glass. Poured an opaque, very dark brown color with small tan head. Aromas of mild malt, husky grain, burnt toast, plums and cherries, smoky hardwood, mild English hops, fruity ale yeast esters. Rich malt sweetness with tartness from hops and roasted barley, toffee, molasses, strong black coffee and  bakers chocolate, tangy flavors of raisin bread, fruitcake. Medium body, full, "chewy" mouthfeel. Very similar to Guinness, but Id say this was a bit less carbonated, less mellow. less creamy, more attenuated, drier, tarter, roastier. Really delicious, I cant wait to find this again.

Bottle from Shangys. Very cool pull top. Pourrs jet black with slight head and some lacing. Nose is Hersheys syrup and frappacino.  First sip is milk chocolate and bittersweet. Coco powder, roasted malt and coffee. Finish iscarame then hoppy bitterness. Great dry stout.
Pours black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is chocolate and coffee.  The mouthfeel is sticky and bitter.

Draught @ Pannuhuone, Kuopio

Pours pitch black with a smooth large, white head. Aroma has notes of roasted malts, coffee, ash and smoke. Taste is quite roasty with notes of smoke, fruits and coffee. Finish is dry and bitter. Well balanced, nice dry stout.

Shared t a tasting, thanks Eyal for this one, pours a brown to black with a medium beige head, aroma of smoked wood, sausage, smoked fish, malt, malt acids and some smoked cheese, flavor is smokey with some cheese, peat, malt and some hops, low sweetness, medium to full bodied, excellent brew

On tap @Black Door, Helsinki. Poured black with a thick, steady beige head. Perfect look. Aroma is roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is chocolate cake, strong espresso  and roasted malt. Dry finish. Excellent stout, probably the best dry stout I have tried so far.

Wein Kultur, Berlin. Tökéletesen fekete szín, krémes világosbarna habbal. Illata erősen pörkölt, maláta, kevés kávé, aszalt szilva és komló érződik. Íze is meglehetősen pörkölt, jó száraz, kicsit füstös, komlós, zöld diós és utóízében enyhén savanykás. Egy jó keserű, nagyon száraz, krémes hatású stout, amely egészen testes, ugyanakkor könnyen iható is egyben.  Nagyon ott van!

Black pour. Huge off-white/light tan head that sticks around the entire time. Little rings of lacing stick to the side as you slowly drink it. Or quickly drink it. Creamy, malty, roasty aroma. Same in the taste, except a little less roast and more cream. A slight hint of vanilla. Smooth and good. Looked exactly like Guinness in ever visible way. But tasted slightly better than the usual draft from Arthur.

Bottle, it pours pitch black with a creamy large tan head..... the aroma is roasted malt, caramel and chocolate..... the flavor is coffee, caramel and roasted malt. light body..... light bitter coffee finish...

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2012 Re-rate 5/30/12: Bottle sample at a tasting at kerenmks place. Thanks beerandbeyond. Very dark brown to black with a bit of beige foam. Aroma of dark fruits, roasted malt and some chocolate. Nice roasty flavor with some cocoa notes and a bitter finish. Medium-bodied. Decent. 6/3/7/3/14=3.3

Re-rate 10/20/11: Bottle sample at a tasting at Dagans place. Thanks zvikar. Black with a light brown head. Smoky aroma with some sausages and coffee. Dry, bitter, smoky flavor with burnt bread and coffee. Medium-bodied. Nice. 7/4/7/3/14=3.5

[9/27/11] Mahleket Hanikot Shotrim 11 tour. Draught at The Wharf in Aalborg. Black-colored with a creamy light brown head. Roasty aroma with coffee, burnt wood notes and a bit of vanilla hints. A rather dry roasty flavor with a bit of sweetish notes at first, some coffee and a burnt bitter finish. Somewhat creamy nitro mouthfeel. A very good Irish Stout. 7/4/7/3/15=3.6
At Charlies Pub in Copenhagen New Year weekend 2010. Dark with a big creamy head. Nice liqorice and tar aroma and flavor.
Bottle at home. Black pour, thick tan head. Aroma is quite roasted, ashy, tobacco, licorice. Flavor is very dry roasted and burnt. Slightly ashy as well. Slightly thin body. Nice though.

Bottle courtesy of Strykzone.  Pours black with a big an head and lots of lacing. Nose is roasted malts.  Body is full and the mouthfeel is rich and creamy. Kind of reminds of the way Guinness used to taste. Good bitter finish.  Lots to like here.
CBF2011: Dark brown coloured. Has a light brown head, mostly lasting. Sweet aroma, caramel, hopped, lightly roasted. Flavor is mostly bitter, dry texture and soft carbonation.

bottle from whole foods Columbus Circle NYC. Acrid at first and sweet. Substantial enough in body with aroma and light flavor of fresh dark Cherry. Bitter hop flavor in some ivy with a chicory frothy light cocoa flavor that is beneath the bitterness and lingers with some bubble gum sweetness. Acrid flavor in air mellows to some smoke and then toasty. Intriguing.

Bottle from Spirits Point Pleasant. Pours a thick dark flat black body with an average size frothy light beige head that looks like shaken chocolate milk. Aroma is dry and sweet with notes of dark bitter chocolate, vanilla, glue, green leafy veggies. The body is fuller and the carbonation is almost nonexistant until you swallow, Finished bitter and bone dry. Flavor of burnt rubber, burnt dark chocolate, green leafy veggies. Blah.

Bottle. Deep brown opaque body, medium to thin tan head. Nose of cocoa puffs, licorice, soy, and a hint of squid aioli. Dry body, bitter and somewhat medicinal with woody roast (sawdust), licorice, soy, and some barely sweet vinous notes. Interesting.

Pours dark chocolate brown, thin tan head. Nose of fig/dates, dough, coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt? Bittersweet taste profile - a hint of hop & fruitiness in the finish. Thin, smooth mouthfeel. Good stuff, definitely on par with Guinness (I would say better). A little pricey for what theyre offering though - I think Old Rasputin or Guinness Extra Stout are good alternatives for a cheaper price. Definitely worth a try though, tasty - this coming from someone who isnt a fan of Stout beer.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2011 Draught at  Porterhouse Coven Garden, London. Deep brown with creamy off-white head. Taste is rich dark chocolate, coffee and malty. Aroma is roasted malts, dark chocolate and caramel. Finish is slightly dry.

330 ml bottle thanks to GT. Pours a totally black hue, completely opaque with a medium light brown head. A sweet caramel and roasted malt nose, some vanilla and lots of metallic roasted notes. The flavor is smooth and rich; earthy, a heaping of heavily roasted malts, some tart metallic/copper flavors, light dried fruit. The finish in the beer is long and very bitter/metallic. A really heavy roasted flavor. Awesome. A ton of flavor here.
Dark brown pour, tan head.  Aroma is very roasty, some spent coffee gain, molasses, and chestnut aroma.  Flavor is very dry, very roasty. Some burned toast, cocoa and espresso.
chocolate, coffee, roasty, butterscotch, woody, black, cloudy, minimal head, light sweetness, very bitter, full body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish,

Bottle. Pours a dark black woth no head but lacinf around the edge of the glass. Smells of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Taste is crisper and lighter then I expected . Almost like a brown ale or porter. Definitely a fulsome bitter sweet stout. Decent

--  Nice oblique black. Ultra-thin beige head. Nose of roasted malt and light chocolate .Light lace. Soft carbonation.  AWESOME flavor of roasted malt, Chocolate and light coffee notes.  Hops will be present after it warms and leaves a nice dry finish on the palate.  Lots of roasted notes in this stout with a light sweetness. Medium bodied with a smooth creamy mouthfeel.  A nice traditional stout, excellent example of the style.   $ 4.49 for a 330 ml bottle, purchased @ Nikkis Liquors in Providence, RI.

Pours a good looking clear and dark brown/black beer with a large beige head. The aroma is malt, roasted, dried fruit and slate. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is roasted with bitterness. Overall a good beer.

11.2 oz. bottle.  A very dark pour with almost no head.  A malty nose that is not that big.  It offers some chocolate, coffee, and grain.  A big flavor that comes right at you.  Huge coffee flavor to start is bitter and dry.  Some dark fruit manages to make it through that coffee but just barely.  The coffee is overpowering and is also over done.
Draught, 5.6%, KØ11. Mildly roasted aroma, slightly papery. Black colour, small light brown head. The flavour is quite roasted with a hint of coffee. Hard roasted barley bitterness.
Sampler at CBF 2011-06-28. Clear deep mahogany with a creamy, brown head. Coffee and other roasted notes on the nose. Roasted milky flavor with some acidity. Full body. Smooth and flatish.
Bottle. Very dark brown medium beige head. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, liquorice, dark fruits, little bitter ans hops.

I searched the world over and thought I found true love....she met another and Thpppppt!....She was gone.  So if this has happened to you, I strongly suggest you find a few of these and consume them in succession.  Bottle provided by Sloth in trade.  Funky grenade pull of a cap will look good with a few magnets glued to it on the fridge.  Dark black pour with thin head. A pungent nose of dark malts, chocolate and a slight licorice tone.  Strangely the bottle was not completely full, yet had not leaked.  I feared the worst. No floaters or sour tone in the glass.  I stoically pushed forward. The short fill (I assume) did not affect the pleasant outcome.  Medium plus body is both creamy and silky as light hops linger in outer rings.  #1000.  Thanks Bertly!

Keg at Porterhouse, Covent Garden. It pours black with a ruby tinge and a thick dense tan head. The nose is roasted malt, smoke and charcoal. The taste is charcoal, toast, rich-roasted malt, liquorice, smoke, bitter chocolate and some caramel, with a long bitter-dry, roasty finish. It is medium bodied and has a creamy mouth-feel. A way above average Irish Stout.

Pours a three finger light brown head that fades quickly to a thin layer leaving a good lace.  Light carbonation and medium-heavy bodied.  Black color, no highlights. Nose is baked chocolate and flavor is roasted-burnt chocolate with a dry bitter finish. $4.85 for a 330ml bottle from Colonial Spirits, Acton, MA. Label has the ABV at 5.7%.

Black pour, large, pretty tan head.  Very nice aroma, has a bit of grainy doughiness to it that I dont encounter a lot in the style, but is rather pleasant.  Plenty of roastiness, of course, and a nice licoricey sweetness.  Tastes sweet and with a bit more of that doughey, grainy flavor, coffee, licorice, dark cherry/currant tones in the middle, and a surprisingly strong and resinous bitter hop finish.  Moderately rich body.  Very nice, would definitely grab it again.  Definitely one of the best Irish beers Ive tried.

Bottle from A Southern Season in Chapel Hill. Pours black with lively tan head. Nose shows lots of British hops. Sweet coffee, grains, and some milk sugars. Taste also shows prominent hops, with sweet grains and coffee briefly showing up briefly before hop bitterness comes back. Finishes bone dry. Palate is thin, but the pleasant dryness makes up for it.
CBF;coffee, chocolate aroma,black, brown foam, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish.

Pitch black coloured body with a touch of a deep cola coloured body when held up to a light with a nice thinnish brown head. Aroma of licorice, aniseed, fennel and anything else that you can think of with that same exact aroma - potent roasty malt of course, but the anise is uncanny. Medium-bodied; Deep assertive roasty flavours at first with the bitter licorice tastes and a deep too burnt coffee like starbucks crap. Aftertaste shows a pungent side with hardly any sweetness, not much complexity and a deep and lingering licorice and roasty flavour with some nuts and earth coming through as well. Overall, not so great - showing too much roasty and aniseed flavours - even for the style. Crazy that I sampled this in a bottle in the states (purchased here too!) but thats how it is sometimes - I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased from Liquor Outlet in Boonton, New Jersey on 08-May-2011 sampled at home in Washington on 03-June-2011, although I can remember the feel of the brewpub in Temple Bar, Dublin on Friday nights when drinking this beer!
Tasted at Copenhagen Beer Festival 2011. Black with nice white head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, dark dried fruit, coffee and chocolate.
Pours dark black with one finger tan head. Nose is papery with notes of day old coffee and shitty chocolate, mild acidic grain. Watery burnt acrid grain with a metallic bite.

Pint in Porterhouse Covent Garden. Pours thick black with foaming white head that retains very well. Thicker than Guinness. Aroma is roasted malt, blackcurrant, and mineral notes. Flavour is mineral, herby notes followed by subtle coffee and chocolate notes.
Draft at Charlies bar, Copenhagen.  Reminded me of Guiness in both appearance and flavor, but slightly more bitter and a little smokey.  (Notes from offline rating)

330ml bottle.
Brown/black, brown head. 
Malty, toasted nose, hops, mint, chocolate. 
Dry, medium body, med bitter. 
Toasted, malty taste, hops, mint, chocolate, spicy, ashes. (2011-05-14)

Bottle 330ml @ home
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate and licorice. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Taste at Wine World. Dark black with a light brown head. Scent is burnt malt and dark chocolate. Taste is burnt malts, coffee and bitter. Good stuff.
Sampled in the small bottle. Pours deep brown or black. Has a pretty rich head on it. The malts are really smooth and roasted to give it a nice balance. Nice brew.

Pours a deep black with ruby hues when held up to the light. The head is nice and leaves plenty of lace. The aroma ia very roasty and a little woody with some black currant. The flavor is very roasty with lots of unsweetened dark chocolate, The beer displays a mild charred character and is very dry featuring a spattering of mild dark fruit throughout. 
Delicious.

A delicious dry stout. Second beer Ive had from this brewery and not disappointed yet. Aroma was a little weak for the style. Thick coffee and deep roasted malt. Pour was a dark black that gives no way to light. Taste was, as the name says, very dry. Nice big rich roasted malt flavors numb the insides of the mouth with bitterness. After the swallow, the mouth dries leaving behind dark coffee. Nice strong prickly carbonation. Very delicious and bitter.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 330ml bottle from Whole Foods Los Altos.  Very dark brown, just slightly translucent, with a one finger tan head and good lacing.  Big aroma, huge on licorice with dark fruit, chocolate cake, and espresso.  Smells great.  The flavor is also big and nice, if a bit heavy on the roasty bitterness and maybe some tannins.  Rather smoky with intense char, licorice, dark chocolate, and coffee.  Very complex.  Dry as hell on the mouthfeel with medium body and a long dry finish.  Damn, this is one hell of a flavor Dry Irish Stout.  Im a fan.
On draft at the Porterhouse brewpub in Dublin.  Black with a nice thick head.  Light aroma of malt and cream.  Pretty light taste for a stout and a smooth palate.  Like a better version of Guinness.

Oddest bottle cap Ive had to open. From the 330 ml. bottle.  The pour is jet black with a long-lasting delicate tan head.  Roasted barley and grain greet the nose along with a moderate coffee aroma.  Full body that holds its own on my tongue but not as creamy as the better known Irish stouts who shall remain nameless.  The taste is slightly bitter with a noticeable dry hop ending.  Very nice traditional stout.
This aint for sissies. Its reminiscent of Guinness Foreign Extra, but I dare say its more bitter. Thumbs up, but probably too bitter for a lot of palates. It appeals to the Irishman in me.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2013 Rerate, draft é Delirium.

Brune foncée, col beige - blanc cassé assez tenace.
Arôme garde un côté houblonné typiquement british et qui est assez dominant. Citronné moyen. Base malt modérée gardant des notes de grillés-caramel et pointe de café.
Palais est agréablement malté, grillé, café avec un profil restant finement amer. Léger mais facile à boire, base malt anglais. Fini augure une pointe de levure, le tout est sec et une bonne bouche avec un bon mariage malt et houblons.  

Draft @ Porterhouse, Dublin.
brune foncée, beige
Houblonné avec note citrus, orge grillé, malt le tout pour une bouche qui reste légèrement amer. Malt grillé est présent pour un palais qui est léger est sec.
Bière légère dont japprécie bien le côté malt grillé ainsi que la balance damertume apporté par le houblon. 7-3-7-3-13

11.2 ounce bottle at The Davis Beer Shoppe.  The aroma has some chocolate along with some mild swampiness and anise.  There is also some roast and light saltiness, too.  Opaque black body with a small tan head and scant lacing present.  Starts with chocolate, roasted, and scant sweetness.  Becomes extremely burnt and ashy with patent and significant hop bitterness.  Pretty brash and harsh.  Not bad, but not worth $5 a bottle...

Bottle, beermerchants.com. Warming coffee and chocolate flavours, a lightish body, a good bitter tang,with a fine soft texture. Like the balance in this beer and I think its fairly far removed from a typical stout.

I had this on nitro at the Map Room into a pint glass...A nice double pour required on this super sticky and totally creamy light tan head that is really not bubbly at all and is almost one solid sheet of head. A boring black beer body leaves not much to discuss...The light aroma of just roasted coffee is boring to my senses and I do not have high hopes for my first sip...The taste confirms this is an amazing looking beer but boring in other regards. A light coffee tastes throughout with an amazingly too bitter coffee finish, very dry and tannic. The flavor after several sips gets worse and despite my most sincere hopes I cannot just crush is 5% beer to end the night and I have to leave it half full.

A too dry and bitter irish stout that almost, almost should be gotten to just look at, or better yet tell someone else to order and just look at the ensuing porn.

Stay away from the bottle though.

Tap at London Porterhouse.  Really nice looking brew, near jet black and a nice cap of darker tan foam.  I honestly could hardly get anything on the aroma for this brew, some faint roasted malt...though nothing off, just really bland in that respect. Light roasted malt, some minerals, and fain chocolate in the flavor.  Creamy and light.

Pours a very dark brown with a mocha head.  Ruby highlights at the edges.  Average lacing.  Significantly darker than the Oyster Stout.

Aroma is rich milk chocolate, milky coffee, molasses, caramel, roasted malt, raisins and some herbal hops.  Its dominated by the chocolate note, which is quite nice.  

The taste starts mildly sweetly with chocolate and coffee and finishes with roast and hop bitterness with a dash of dark malt acidity.  Theres some good stout flavor in there.  The aftertaste is rather hoppy.

Mouthfeel is creamy and full.  Relatively low carbonation.

Bottle listed at 5.7%. Pours with a deep black body with a khaki colored head that stays well and leaves very nice lacing. Aromas of roasted barley, grainy, caramel with noticeable esters (pear and other fruits. Rich cocoa and coffee notes which are pretty intense for a dry stout. Medium notes of earthy and woodsie british hops. Flavors are dry with roast. Roasted barley makes itself noticed with its sharpness. Dry, coffee grounds. Light caramel and bitterness. Finishes with a very light acidity. Estery. Light hop notes in the finish. Light carbonation yet has a creamy consistency. No alcohol warmth. Slight mouthbending astringency from the roasted barley. A classic interpretation of the style.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2012 11.2 oz. bottle shared by Matt at The Royale. He picked it up at either TWCP or Randalls. Pours a dark brownish-copper color with a small, creamy tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, grass, grains, sugar, toast, and chocolate. Flavor of chocolate, rust, dark pit fruits, dry coffee, and nuts. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a roasty, somewhat acidic mouthfeel. Nice, drinkable, sessionable dry stout. Re-Rate, 1/3/12: This is a lot better on nitro; pours a really attractive cascading milky brown. Very smooth and chocolaty. Nice.
UPDATED: AUG 29, 2011 Black colour beer with a creamy off-white head. Smokey roasted aroma.  Flavor is roasted, again little smokey with a longer bitter malty strong ending. Very nice stout.

Bottle.  Pours a clear but very dark garnet with a frothy sticky foamy dark head.  Aroma of dry coffee, lightly fruity ester note, creamy chocolate.  Flavor follows, dry coffee and light fruit upfront, a bit of acidity follows finishing with a nice coffee roast and longer bitter hop aftertaste.  Simple, super well made, and very balanced.  Very drinkable.  Med bodied, smooth watery feel with a bit of grit and soft carbonation.
Definitely dry, with a discernable chocholate flavor to it.  A very good Dry Stout, probably the best to come out of Ireland.

Bottle from beermerchants.com.Pours black with a small creamy beige head. Aroma of roasted coffee, taste is the same but with a good light burnt malty touch to it. Aftertaste is ood dark roasted malts, with a nice hoppy bitter bite at the end. Quite good for the low abv.
First Porterhouse beer.  Very dry and roasted aroma and flavor with a good amount of hops to add some bitterness.  Also has a noticeable smoke quality as well.  A good dry stout.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a deep black with little to no head. Smooth medium to light body which is very drinkable. Nice well balanced hints of dark malts, and very slight coffee coming through. Not too dry or bitter of a finish, a solid Irish Stout although not that dry. Overall: (B)
From a bottle poured a dark brown color with a fair amount of head.  Strong toasted bitter malty flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

Bottle.  Glad this came over the Atlantic, since they were out of it when I was actually in Dublin.  Dark ruby color with a large, falling head.  Strong roasted barley aroma with a fair amount of ale yeast fruitiness.  Very strong roasty flavor.  Light chocolate.  Quite acrid and bitter, not all from hops, either.  A little too abrasive to be a session stout, but enjoyable.
Bottle from BevMo Arden. Pours black with a modest tan head and a burnt caramel aroma. There is a hearty treacle and smoked malt flavor with a dry bitter finish.

Cask at Charlies pub, Copenhagen. Dark amber color, brownish head, that is creamy and rather lasting. Roasted malt aroma, some chocolate. Roasted flavor, soot, metal and chocolate. Rather discreet balanced finish.
Black with a creamy light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee and a little burnt. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a dry finish. 251210

Bottle. Poured black with a creamy light brown head that settled to a ring with time. Roast aroma combined with dark chocolate. The flavor found roasted malt and coffee. Light to medium body and a lasting roast aftertaste.

Bottle.  Near black with a beige foam.  Aromas are rich roast coffee with liquorice and hints of blackberry.  Earthy and oily with leather.  Fruity light grapefruit hops with some pine needles. 330ml Bottle:  Aroma of roasted malt, bakers chocolate, slight soy sauce, and a hint of peat. Cool 11.2 oz. bottle with the grenade type pull cap.  Consumed fresh, the day it hit the shelves in Orlando.  Pours a dark mahogany color with some chestnut tinted translucency at the outer layers.  A quickly fleeting head of smooth khaki foam gives way to a thin surface film, as scant traces of lacing dot the glass in its wake.  The nose is something of a beautiful contradiction, dry and roasty on one hand, yet sweet, chocolaty, and fruity on the other.  Notes of toasted, perhaps even smoked barley are joined by coffee and dry cocoa in an effort to balance out sweeter chocolate, licorice, and burnt toffee elements.  Some unidentifiable dark fruit lends further sweetness in the background, while potent green, herbal, grassy hops lend an aromatic punch.  Flavors are largely the same, towing the line between dry roast bitterness and sweeter caramel and blackened malt notes.  Cocoa, coffee, and scorched caramel all again play their part, while a hint of salty brininess reminds me of an oyster stout.  Bitter, grassy hopping concentrates on the long, ashy, roasty finish.  Each swallow of the light-bodied (for a stout anyway) liquid brings with it a drier, more parching sensation, low carbonation leading into a papery, bitter end point.  Overall, I find this to be interesting and unique stuff, but nothing groundbreaking or even remotely impressive.  I want to call it sessionable, but that is largely untrue for me as the dryness gets to be excessive by the 3/4 mark of the drink.  Decent brew....nothing more, nothing less.

Bottle with the pull-tab top.  Big stouty nose, rich chocolate and a ton of deep, dark, ashy roast, a rough-and-tumble foreign stout without any of the fruit or overblown alcohol. Taste is brutally dry with low-medium bitterness, gobs and gobs of roast and ash with some hop bite.  Key here is the depth of roast flavor - there are several levels to explore if one goes digging.  Light-medium body, a hint of acidic tang but thats backed off in favor of some roast barley (which is pushing the limits of the terms association with astringency toward territory governed by black patent).  A delightful experience, though probably not one for the daily pint: an earthy, uncompromisingly manly stout.

Nose of toasted malt, chocolate, ground coffee and a touch of hops.  It wasnt fair to this beer having tried it after a barrel aged Barley Wine.  A pretty well made dry stout none the less.

Thick tan collar with surprising gritty hops, ash and singed barley leaking out from beneath. Got the Galena without looking. Proper grown-up burnt toast and dry hop bitterness. Fat nitro body, herbaceous hops creeping out as it warms (thaws). Ashtray afters clinging with smoke. Punches with roast and hops. Impressive.

Draught, Porterhouse, Dublin. Great looking stout, with improbably dark body and off-cream head. Complex on the nose, of roasted malt, chocolate, hops, yeast. Quite bitter on the palate, but equally rounded too. Not this drinker’s particular preference, but would be the ideal stout for others I’m sure.

750mL bottle.  Opened unenthusiasticallly, but looked good when poured.. deep brown with a creamy cap of rich tan head.  The aroma picked up roasted coffee, semi-sweet chocolate, and lesser nutty notes in a fine array of malts.. just a touch of oaky sourness and herbal notes behind.  The flavor had a little more sourness than I would’ve liked, but it was still aiight.. roasted barley, coffee, and lesser chocolate on the core with oak and roasted grainy sourness around.. bitterness was fresh and greener with grassy character.. finished with roasted black malts and more of that sourness.  Medium-bodied with ideal carbonation on the palate, but the sourness kept it from flowing well.  Certainly solid overall

Draught @ The Porterhouse, Covent Garden. Mahogany with a thick beige nitro head. Dark chocolate, roast malts, black filter coffee and a hint of soap in the nose. Slightly thin in the mouth but has good roasty notes, baking chocolate and some bitter hops in the finish.

Aroma is dominated by roasted coffee and liquorice, cocoa notes too, black, sporting a tiny toffee head. Taste is unbeatable coffee, gorgeous liquorice, fine dark chocolate. Medium bodied, superbly balanced, bitter and bold. Incredible! Thanks Torontoblue.

Tap @ Porterhouse, London.
Pours almost black with a great, staying, creamy, beige head. Exceptionally good looks. Sweet, malty aroma, some chocolate and soft roasted. Not much of it, though. Low carbonation, fine, creamy mouthfeel - much like a good Guinness. Flavour is rather sweet and malty, good dark chocolate, nuts, liquorice and a great, long aftertaste.

750 ml bottle sent from Secret Santa 2008.  Quite dark with a bubbly brown head.  Very roasty aroma with licorice.  Sharp but semi-sweet with roasted/burnt grain.  Complex with a bit of malt with earthy/spicy hop presence that is not over done. Solid.  Carbonated medium body with semi-dry finish.  Pretty good for a style I do not usually get into.

750, corked and baled. Thanks, BitBucket! This was truly above and beyond the call without a doubt. The cork was a real SOB to remove--ended up chipping glass off the neck TWICE, using a garden variety wine bottle opener. This was after I gave up messing with the cork and just cut the top off. wtf? Impacted to say the least. But that’s neither here nor there wrt the beer, since I rinsed the shards off the top under the tap.
Pours a jet-black body under a thick, surging, moussy burnt tan head. Plenty of webby lacing left as it falls, but it sticks around to some degree for a good long while. Sweet licoricey nose...delectable. Creamy medium body. Plenty of chocolate and licorice on the mid-palate with whiffs of licorice darting in for cameos here and there. Long, mild, creamy finish. This isn’t really a 750 beer, it’s a 6-pack beer, but it’s lovely stuff. Could drink a fair bit of it if they got the price down where it ought to be, instead of hovering around 75 cents an ounce in the states at boutique bottle shops.
The 4X is my favourite stout from the Porterhouse brewery. It has the strongest taste, and it keeps you thinking.

Moderately, off-white head resting all the way on top of a pitch black body. Sweet coffee aroma. Roasted coffee beans in flavour turning into more coffee grounds towards the ending. Bitter finish (third pint glass on a sample tray, draught at Porterhouse London 05.08.2008).

Corked bottle and served in my Stone IRS snifter: Opaque with a frothy tan head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of heavy roasted and charred malts, aromatic herbal hops, anise, pipe tobacco, plum, and a hint of coffee esters. The taste starts with a nice balance of burnt black malt and hop bitterness balanced by bready pale malts. Hint of lactic twang and acidic fruit around the edges. The finish has some liquorice and chocolate notes along with a dry ashy character. There is a strange but welcomed salty like quality on the aftertaste. The mouth feel is round and lively, good for the style. Pretty darn nice beer but not too sure if worth the monies however.
Awesome stout on draught at the Porthouse in Dublin.  This is very thick and full of wonderful dark flavors.  Coffee and dark fruit.  Burnt carmel and good amount of bitterness.

Draught at Porterhouse, Black coloured beer with an average creamy off-white head and a sweeter special, light smokey roasted aroma. Full smokey creamy palate. Finish is roasted, again little smokey with a longer bitter malty strong ending. Very nice stout.

Draught at Porterhouse Central; dublin.

Dark brown with a small, beige head.
Fruity, citric aroma with some chocolate-toffee.
Roasted flavour with a lot of dry cocoa-bitterness.

Dark with a deep beige head.  Aroma is roasted malts, vanilla, lactose, molasses, chocolate and alcohol.  Medium bodied and well carbonated, but still goes down easy.  Flavor is roasted, chocolate, malty, vanilla, and some earth.  Easy drinking, damn tasty stout.  Nothing overpowers here, just a solid combination that makes me think I need a few more bottles.

pours a thick black (opaque) with a large brown bubbly head.
smell is cocoa, touch of coffee, licorice, slight vanilla, a whiff of smoke.
taste is thick creamy, dark and bakers chocolate, touch of espresso, end is dry and slightly bitter, a woody aftertaste.

Pitch black color with a dark brown head. The nose is very unique with strong salty black licquorice, dark chocolate, treacles, and tobacco notes. Did I mention how salty this is? Very dry and intense mouth with salty black licquorice, dark chocolate and dark fruit. Sightly warming. Med body.  Saltiness just lingers in the mouth. Truely an amazing stout that is not getting its props.

The aroma is dusty, detergenty with some dark fruit and dark roasted malt. The body is black with a crazy lasting, thick mocha head. The first sip is sweet chocolate, fruity, malty and it has a very creamy feel. Lingering ashy, sweet fruit flavor with a bit of astringency.
@ Porterhouse, Dublin: Black, long lasting cafe au lait head, notes of coffee, liquorice, chocolate, roasted malt,mainly bitter and dry finish.

(Draught at Porterhouse on 2008-07-01) Almost black. Medium-sized dense tan head. Almost burned aroma in nose. Full and dry palate. Hops, roasted malts and lots of bitterness in taste. Sligtly boring. Ok aftertaste.

Thanks Tom/After4ever. It’s a black beer with a huge, nice, creamy and nougat colored head. The aroma is mild and has notes of roasted malt, coffee and licorice. The flavour has a light sweetness, notes of chocolate, coffee, licorice, roasted malt and it’s smooth with a nice body. It’s really not very complex, but it’s uncomplicated and very harmonic and constantly invites to another sip, then another etc. I like it a lot!

Poured impenetratably jet black with a light brown, long-lasting, tight head.  The aroma surprised me a bit as I got more hop aroma than roasted barley.  Still though, the roasted factor was nicely presented around a very complex chocolate, brown sugar and balanced EKG herbal note.  The flavor was great as well though more molasses-like than in the aroma with a great dry, roasty and lightly grainy/astringent lingering finish.  Very creamy in the middle and nice and dry in the finish.  Good use of flaked barley.  This is a really nice beer that actually hides its 7% alcohol pretty well.  I could drink a lot of these and nothing else over a night, and be very, very happy.

A very strong powerful stout with distinct flavourings of roasted malt and tobacco.The tobacco was unusual but i quite liked it.hint of coffee and more roasted malt in the finish. Took a few pints but im starting to like it a lot

Bottle:  Dark brown pour with a nice sized tan head.  Aroma is roasty and sweet, light cocoa and coffee.  Flavor is again roasty and sweet with a bittersweetness too.  The roast is just right and really takes the center of the brew.  Thanks BuckDich.
On tap at The Porterhouse, Covent Garden 29 Apr 08. Black with a creamy light brown head. Modest aroma of chocolate. Flavor of roasted malt and chocolate. A pleasant dry roasted finish.

Bottle: Thick black color, tan head and nice light lacing. Nose of licorice, sharp astringency, some molasses and coffee. The flavor is bitter, some mild almond, coffee, cherry and chocolate notes. Bright astringency, dry mouthfeel and a nice creamy balanced tail. Good dry stout, high acidity, easy drinkability and a minerally note.

Pour:  Deep black, brown edges, 3-finger tan head, great lacing
Nose:  roasty choc malt, molasses, fig, almond, brown sugar, perfumy florals late
Taste:  Roasty choc malty, dry, slight rauchy, molasses, almond, walnut
Overall:  Medium palate heft, nicely balanced, this is a truly great stout that, should I ever vist the Emerald Isle, I will seek out ahead of Guinness and Murphys.
Black colored, moderate sized tan head, pretty good lacing and retention. Aroma is chocolate with some roasted goodness. Medium bodied, quite dry. Not bad.
Dark in color, nice brown head. Toasty and malty in flavor, a bit smoky-sweet with flavors of coffee and licorice. Dry and mild.

Bottle shared by Humulone_Red. Thanks!
Pours dark black with a thin light tan head.  Smell is roasty and somewhat mild.  Taste is rich dark roasted malt and a very light bit of coffee in the flavor.  Slightly bubbly mouthfeel, but this was pretty good overall and nicely drinkable.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2008 Dark brown color with a tall somewhat diminished tan head, that leaves a heavy sheet of lace. Somewhat interesting in aroma, with some roasted malt, touch of smoke, and mineral water. Touches of licorice and menthol as well. Just from the first sip I would consider this a foreign or sweet stout. Heavy malt flavors from the start. Roasted malt, with cream and dark chocolate. Middle starts to dry out in this one. Some black and roasted malt flavors. Some lactic qualities come out as it warms. It also seems to be more like a dry stout as it warms. Some light spice in the finish.

This isnt a style that often excites me (the consumate hop-head), but I enjoyed this brew.  From the bottle this poured a dense, intense dark brown body capped by a huge light brown head that turned rocky after a while, coating the glass with clumps of lace.  Big roasted aroma, barley-malt-coffee, with dark chocolate, anise, and cigar tobacco.  The flavor is more straightforward in the ways of a dry Stout, very roasty, but with a smooth blending of the sensations from the nose into the mouth.  The finish is quite dry and has a mild burnt hard nut bitterness to it.  Nice.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine & Spirits, Downers Grove, IL<font size=-1>

Medium creamy beige everlasting head. Opaque black body goes dark red at edges. Burnt milky caramelly aroma. Dry burnt coffee and grain taste with milky licorice notes. Burnt almonds and caramel also in evidence. Peppery aftertaste. Very nice and drinkable dry stout. Pretty uncompromising. (0.3l  draft at Porterhouse Temple Bar, Dublin.)

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2011 Have no idea where my earlier rating came from, where did I have this before?...Anyway, the re-rate is from Dublin at Porterhouse brewery taps...revisited many times, this beer is great! And the numbers stay the same!

Opaque black. Cappucino-colored head. The nicest-looking of all the Porterhouse stouts. Aroma has a Mexican chocolate profie with fun ancho pepper smoke. Yeah. Very soft mouthfeel from nitro but also luscious good beer...The ancho and well-smoked earthy chili pepper character is all over the mouth and makes this a unique and excellent brew. Impressive!


Luscious thick tan head on a black body. Aroma of cocoa and blackberry. Clean, simple, solid flavors. A little fizzy in the palate. A super-nice enjoyable dry stout.

750 ml bottle poured a translucent brownish black with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of alkali, carmel, bitter chocolate and light coffee. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth with a slightlyt dry finish. Flavors of esspresso, dark chocolate, carmel, light vanilla and a hint of smoke with a smooth lingering lightly bitter finish.Flat out smokes Guiness!!!

Bottle from Michael Jacksons Beer of the Month Club. Probably should of had this before the StArnolds #5 but anyway. Little to zero aroma here. Roastiness, light coffee feel. Very drinkable & enjoyable

Pours pitch black and completely opaque, with a very dark tan head with brown highlights. Aroma is almost all coffee, but with notes of dark fruit in the background, and hints of hops. Flavor is dry, even a bit dusty, but with big espresso character, all backed by some definite hop character. Body is very creamy and smooth. Aftertaste is more coffee, dry from the roast malts, and slightly hoppy. Little on the bitter side in the tail. Nice stout, lots more flavor than Guinness.

Draught @ Porterhouse, Coven Garden. Pours a black color with a longlasting creamy tan head. Roasted malty aroma with some hints of chocolate. Roasted malty chocolate and coffee flavor. Long roasted malty finish with a slightly bitter aftertaste.

750 from Michael Jacksons Beer Club. Label says 7% abv. Its quite a nice dry stout, with a nice chocolatey aroma and a bit of smoke in there. As the beer warms, some roast and barley in there, and a pleasing milky consistency that goes well with the chocolatey qualities. Not too much personality, and a bit thin, but Id happily drink this again.

Bitter for a dry stout, but still solid and enjoyable. Fizzy light brown head above a dark, opaque body. The heavy aroma presents smells of roasted and burnt malts, molasses, coffe, smoke and hops. The flavor is lightly sweet, heaviy acidic and moderate to heavily bitter. Very dry and somewhat chalky finish. Medium body.

On tap at The Porterhouse, Covent Garden, London.
Deep black coloured, creamy head, chocolate nose. Roasted malt and chocolate aroma with chicory notes and strong bitter finish. Very nice and heavy stout.

Courtesy of Degarth. Pours black with explosive rocky mocha head and crazy sheet lacing. The aroma has a moment of roasty to burnt malts before a big malted-fig-cotton-ball smell rears up. Odd. The taste starts with mild dark fruitiness from figs, dates and prunes before roasty, mild chocolate malts, malt balls, some vanilla and burnt malts join the fray. Yum. It ends with mostly malt notes and some rich dark chocolate.
Frsh off the tap this was a dark brown topped night.  A fine stout with a strong hop attack at the back, and a deep flavour of roast.

750ml bottle, MJ Rare Beer Club, marked as 7% ABV:  Black as night pour with an incredibly thick and creamy tan head.  Wow, this is hoppy for a dry stout.  The nose is orange and lemon juice and zest, pine and perfume on top of a soft, bitter chocolate note.  Roasted coffee and dark chocolate dominate the body.  Finishes a bit chalky and dry on the tongue.

Courtesy of Degarth. Thanks Joe. Was nice to see I hadnt rated this one, I had it at a previous tasting but must have never taken notes on it. Oh well, stoutie ratings rule. Brown body with a light tan head. Very fluffy, nice lasting power and lacing. Smell is a bit odd, some detergent or soap powder, also some fruity esters, licorice, chocolate, coffee and some charred malts. Flavor is similar, but thankfully dropping much or all of the detergent note, and leaving just a pretty good dry stout behind. Body is appropriate to style, drinks very easily. Finish is short to medium in length, a bit bitter or astringent with some coffee and chocolate notes.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2008 Keg (Porterhouse, Dublin)
Black, nitro head. In the most recent one I had, nitro kills the aroma, but some darkly roasted malts detectable. Rich roasted malty taste - sweet but bitter chocolate. Dry, punchy and bitter - an excellent Irish stout. Had previously with more aroma - much improved the experience, and old higher rating preserved. Let this warm, and swirl some of the gas out of it to appreciate it best.
Roasted coffee and chocolate with hoppy aroma. Hoppy and bitter aftertaste with a beige head. Mouth feel is very silky smooth. A very nice stout.
Draft @ Porterhouse, Coven Garden. Deep brown with creamy off-white head. Taste is rich dark chocolate, coffee and malty. Aroma is roasted malts, dark chocolate and caramel. Finish is slightly dry.
Dark brown with large creamy head. This was a very good beer with huge roasted flavors throughout. smooth and creamy on the palate. Puts that other famous Irish stout to shame.

This is a huge beer, expecially for its strength. Dark brown, thick creamy yellow head. It looks fantastic. It has a really strong burnt taste with a huge bitter finish. The best Irish stout Ive tasted.

Bottle Shared with Hogtown Harry and Blankboy, courtesy of Hogtown Harry (thanks Swoopjones!!) Wow, big thanks to Harry for sharing this one, Ive always wanted to try something from these guys.  With a label that claims that theyre modeling their beer after the stuff Michael Collins and crew used to drink, well, thats pretty neat too, here goes.  Dry dry dry aroma - dusty, sweet with some chocolate - good start.  Pitch black, medium brownish head.  Very dry taste - great full body, molasses, chocolate, some hops.  Milky.  Very drinkable.  A wonderful session dry stout that exceeded my very high expectations.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2010 
Date: June 02, 2007
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting
Appearance: black, wispy beige head
Aroma: dry roasted malt and dark chocolate aroma
Flavor: rich bitter dark chocolate flavor, only a touch of sweetness at first but disappears as it gets warm, picks up a light tartness upon warming

Date: April 10, 2010
Mode: bottle
Source: hop city
Appearance: black, frothy beige head
Aroma: dry roasted aroma
Flavor: rich roasted flavor, lots of dark chocolate bitterness, touch of sweetness eventually emerges, long bitter finish

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 2.9/5.0Drinkability: 6/10
Score: ** /4

MJs Rare Beer Club 7/13/07:  Black body w/a lasting medium sized beige head.  Metallic w/ sherry like oxidation at first in the aroma, then prunish dark fruit esters.  Also minerally.  Very light chocolate & roasted grains and a touch of soapy hops with hints of toasted and caramel malts.  The flavor is well balanced between sweet and bitter up front, but finishes bitter and lingers into the aftertaste.  Light chocolate malt, and again, a soapy flavor w/ herbal and earthy hop presence.  Brown sugary at the start and some lightly toasted malt.  Light raisiny ester in the flavor and also a touch of alcohol.  Fuller medium body, warming alcohol, low carbonation, and a dry m/f.  Okay but not great!  A bit too harsh around the edges to be truly enjoyable for me.

Bottle (750ml) shared with HogTownHarry & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours an impenetrable dark brown with a large mostly-lasting fluffy light-brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, fresh green hops, cocoa and a hint smoke -- very unique aroma. Flavours dry with lightly roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and a nice amount of hops. Medium bodied, smooth creamy mouthfeel. A somewhat unique and very enjoyable Stout.

Off-white head, with a dark brown body. Caramel and roasted malt aromas. Lots of roasted malts in the taste along with the bitter chocolate and the coffee. Noticable hops in the taste as well. More bitter than most stouts are methinks. I expected more, but I got something respectable.
This beer is great on draught!  Far, far better tasting than Guinness. Lots of hoppy flavour. Go to Dublin and try it!

Bottle (750ml).  Shared with blankboy and tupalev, my bottle from swoopjones.  Poured thick, opaque brown-black with a large fluffy light brown lasting head (4+).  I cant decide whether the pungent grassy/funky UK hops or the dry, mildly spicy dark roasted molasses/nutoil/dark chocolate malt dominates - its roasty, dry and funky.  (tupalev says it reminds him of burnt dust, like when you fire up the electric space heater for the first time in the fall) - very good.  Taste - smooth, soft, chocolate milk, dry, darkly roasty, milky, green funky hops - smooth.  Lovely mouthfeel - lightish body for a stout, but silky and milky, mily carbonation, malty linger - excellent - I think I liked it the most of the three of us, but we all like it.  Dry, but not too dry.  Note:  bottle said 7%, not 5% - felt more like 5% to me.

Black colour, mediumsized brown creamy and thick head. Aroma is roasted malts, very dark chocolate and some caramel. Flavour is big roasted malts, some dark chocolate and strong coffee and fudge. Really wellbalanced and pleasant to drink. Roasted nice aftertaste.

Bottle - 750mL corked and caged from the Michael Jackson Rare Beer Club. Ive had this in the fridge since I got it. Not sure why I waited so long to rate it. Black pour. Midnight really. Bit of mahogany around the edges at the surface. Small tan head is gone before I was done pouring, it seemed. Nose is roasted malts, sweet caramel, coffee and cream, and dark chocolate. Taste is a bit more on the bitter side as compared with the aroma. Strong roasted maltiness, cold coffee, dark, bittersweet chocolate and soft burnt caramel. Body is creamy and smooth but fizzy is spots, especially as you start to swallow the last gulp of each mouthful. Finishes with more bittersweet chocolate, dark coffee, roasted malts and more caramel notes. Nothing unique or extreme, but well done, nonetheless. Very drinkable!

Dark brown pour with rustic crimson hues. A creamy light brown head disperses rapidly. the aroma is of sweet coffee, moderate roasted grains, burned caramel, astringent but not alcoholic at all. The flavor is very astringent, with just a touch of sweetness, hints of acrid smoke, torched caramel and unpleasant in many regards. The taste took a total nosedive. The finish is bitter, burnt, medium in duration and leaves sour roastiness lingering. Mouthfeel is tingly, adequately carbonated and dull, somewhat scattered. Interesting but not very drinkable.

750 mL bottle caged and corked. poured an opaque black color. Head was thin and tan. Smelled of dark chocolate and a bit of adhesive tape. Roasty and dry on the tongue with some chocolate and weak coffee flavors. A bit thinner than I had expected.
Barely got any notes for this one written down. Had some light roasty chocolate to this. Pretty tastey though for a dry stout.

25 oz bottle, via jjpm74.  Pours a dark black body under a rather large two inch foamy brown head.  Lots of visible carbonation retains head for the duration.  The nose is quite roasty and chocolaty with a nice hoppy note, with some light licorice and burnt notes.  The flavor is really well balanced with the burnt and roasted malts lending that classic dryness without being too astringent, then finishing with a lingering english hoppiness and a little chalk.  Mouthfeel is smooth and silky with very light soft carbonation.  The head must have taken away the carbonation thankfully.  The texture is watery, but not thin.  This was a really nice beer.  Quite flavorful and with a good amount of complexity for a Dry Stout.  A little under-rated in my opinion.

Thanks for bringing this to a tasting, General_Gao. The body was black with a light orange colored head. The aroma was sweet chocolate with vanilla. The taste was soybeans with some coffee. There was also a bit of chocolate and a bitter finish. The body was very smooth. A good stout that I would like to try again.

Appearance: Pours a black opaque body with a creamy khaki-colored head. 

Smell: Mild aroma of roasted malts, light caramel, and one tiny handful of nuts, all hedged by a definite sourness.

Taste: Roasted malt flavors of coffee and dark chocolate with, again, just a smattering of nuts. However, all the flavors are rather muted, except for that sourness. A decent amount of roastiness with just a bit of hops on the finish. Some alcohol peaks through now and again, which seemed surprising for a beer thats listed at 5%.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Soft carbonation.

Drinkability: I didnt care for this one at all.

Pours a mostly opaque black with a nicely-lacing light brown head.  Dry, earthy roasty aroma has some bittersweet dark chocolate notes and fresh American hops.  Body starts slightly tart and very dry with some earthy notes and a roasty finish.  Goes well with dark chocolate, but could use a little sweetness on its own.

On tap at the Porterhouse Dublin. Opaque black body with a creamy tan head. Aroma of coffee. Taste of coffee, chocolate with a double shot of espresso in the finish. This beer tastes big even after tasting two other Porterhouse stouts.

A very good stour this.  Much better than the overrated and overhyped Guinness, which is drunk by gormless posers.  This is a stout that the Irish should be proud of and should be drunk much more widely than its evil cousin.  Sweet and caramel in taste, but what I like the most is the long lasting dry bitter aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2011 Pours a lovely stout black, toffee aroma with a coffee and toffee punch!!!!! Very very enjoyable tap stout, will certainly drink again

Rerate 4 years later, just some additional notes: Bitter, dark chocolate, leather, malt, espresso finish. Delicious.
Bottle.  Poured dark with smoky aroma.  Smoke and chocolate flavor.  Good all around stout.

C-bus 7.  Light roasted malt.  Black body with a thin head.  Medium palate.  Lightly bitter toasted malts and some hints of coffee.  Some grassy flavors show up now to make this more complex and are joined by an astringent malt flavor that detracts from the flavor.

Bottle... Pitch black ale with a small, fizzy, white head. The nose is of coal dust and cocoa powder. Burnt, bitter flavor with no residual sweetness. Bursts of dark chocolate and espresso. Full-bodied and astringent with soft carbonation. Bitter, acrid finish.  A big SHOUT goes out to jjpm74 for providing the bottle!

Poured a very dark brown color with no real head.  Sweetish lacto roast aroma, with some dark chocolate.  Medium-bodied, mildly carbonated.  Mild roast character in taste, with a clean, dry finish.  A decent dry stout.

750ml bottle from footy - thanks Rudy! - Shared this one at Columbus 7 tasting - Pours dark brown with a short offwhite head.  Aromas of smoky roasted malts over chocolate and caramel.  Flavor is quite roasty as well with a good amount of smoke there.  Some good sweetness finds its way through with notes of caramel and chocolate.  Smooth and rich throughout with a nice dry finish.  I really enjoyed this one.
poured black with a small khaki head.Hugh aromas of hops, floral and dirt.Hoppy flavor with hints of chocolate peeking out.Finish was slightly hoppy and bitter.

Pours a pitch black with an off white head.  Nice roasty and chocolatey aromas fill the nostrils.  Just a touch of some coffee too, but not much.  The mouthfeel is rather creamy and full.  Big roastiness on this beer, which has a little nuttiness to it as well mixed in with some chocolate.  Nice flavor.  Pretty good brew.

C-Bus 7 Bottle shared by Ohiodad: Poured black with a tan head. Aroma roasted malts, bready, toasted notes. Flavor, roasted malts, some nuts, coffee, and pretty dry. Some roasted bitterness on the finish. Medium to full bodied. Very nice.

7% ABV carbonated 750ml bottled version.  Pours dark brown with a giant generous light brown/tan head.  Smells of dough, nuts, pepper, hints of roasted malt, chocolate, spices, some hints of peatiness.  Tastes of chocolate, hints of cherries, pepper, dark fruit and lots of complimentary roasty qualities.  Some interesting earthy qualities emerge as the beer warms.  Mouthfeel is full and lightly tangy with a spice/tarte finish.

thru Michael Jackson Rare Beer Club.  Creamy chocolate and vanilla with coffee, cafe mocha all on the nose.  Pours black with a thick tan head that lasts.  Heavy coffee flavor, with chocolate notes, strong roasted barley flavor, vanilla, so so so creamy even without nitro.  So good!!!  Best stout ive had out of the emerald isle!

750 ml bottle from Micheal Jacksons Rare Beer Club. Pure black in color with the best head of any stout I have seen. Three fingers of full and frothy mocha foam, lots of bubbles. Dark roasted malts, coffee, bitter chocolates, and mellow hops in the nose. Loved the aroma but was a bit faint in my opinion. Full bodied and fairly complex, but this one is a little bitter for my taste.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2008 A Mes rate: Nitrotap @ The House of Porter.Looks like the best looking Guinness you have ever seen. Head almost has the texture of mousse. When a bubble pops it leaves a permanent crater. Aroma is inky and rubbery with some dark chocolatey malt and just a lick of hops. Flavour is pretty much as the nose with a little extra black coffee. Just a tiny bit too bitter from a clear hoppy finish. A fine stout.

Tap. All black. Creamy, light brown head. Plenty of aroma, like burned malt and cinnamon. Well balanced flavour of roasted malt and fruit. Continues to a smooth finish with bitterness and coffee. (Porterhouse Dublin 16.03.07)

Dark ruby black with a nitro tan head and thin lacing, the Wrasslers is undoubtedly Porterhouses most attractive beer. A step up from the Oyster Stout, Wrasslers features a deeper dark chocolate nose that pairs remarkably with rich noble hops and a hint of Roquefort. Balanced on the palate, its agreeable coffee and hop bitterness shares the tongue with a hint of orange peel. A relatively one-dimensional stout but that dimension is quite enjoyable, and surely the most full-flavored of Porterhouses offerings. An elegant ale and at 5% one that I could drink several pints of.

Solid black appearance with a creamy head. Full flavoured dry stout with the alcohol rearing its head amongst the malty, treacle-like taste. Very bitter aftertaste that dries out the pallet very quickly. Not suited for a session.

On tap at Porterhouse. This was my favorite of the 10 Porterhouse beers I tried. It looks very much like a Guinness. The smell is of wheat and the taste is quite bitter, as well as chocolate. Very foamy, nice and black. With smooth finish.

Draught @ Porterhouse, WC2 London. Dark black color with a creamy light-brown head. Aroma is very light - malty, burnt, dark chocolate. Flavor is harsh bitter dry, burnt, hops. Was served very cooled but did get much better when it was warmed up.

Draught - Porterhouse, London.  A black coloured stout with a nasty nitro creamy head.  The aroma is dry and roasty with some cream effect from the head.  The taste is very dry and burnt but there is also a bittering hop quality to add to the burntness.  A strongly flavoured quite decent beer.
A rich roast malty stout with lots of hops. The best of Prterhouses Stout by a long way.
